ScreenDetailed.summary: NOTE Experimental The ScreenDetailed interface of the Window Management API represents detailed information about one specific screen available to the user's device.

remarks.para: ScreenDetailed objects can be accessed via the and properties.

ScreenDetailedAvailLeft.summary:
NOTE Experimental The availLeft read-only property of the
interface is a number representing the x-coordinate (left-hand edge) of the available screen area inside the OS virtual screen arrangement, relative to the multi-screen origin.

remarks.para: This is equal to the property, plus the width of any OS UI element drawn on the left of the screen. Windows cannot be placed in those areas, so availLeft is useful for giving you the left boundary of the actual area available to open or place windows.

blockquote.para: A non-standard implementation of the availLeft property is available on the Screen interface in all browsers. See the Non-standard example below for usage details, and see the Screen reference page for browser support information relating to the non-standard implementation.

ScreenDetailedAvailTop.summary:
NOTE Experimental The availTop read-only property of the
interface is a number representing the y-coordinate (top edge) of the available screen area inside the OS virtual screen arrangement, relative to the multi-screen origin.

remarks.para: This is equal to the property, plus the height of any OS UI element drawn at the top of the screen. Windows cannot be placed in those areas, so availTop is useful for giving you the top boundary of the actual area available to open or place windows.

blockquote.para: A non-standard implementation of the availTop property is available on the Screen interface in all browsers. See the Non-standard example below for usage details, and see the Screen reference page for browser support information relating to the non-standard implementation.

ScreenDetailedIsInternal.summary:
NOTE Experimental The isInternal read-only property of the
interface is a boolean indicating whether the screen is internal to the device or external. External devices are generally manufactured separately from the device they are attached to and can be connected and disconnected as needed, whereas internal screens are part of the device and not intended to be disconnected.
ScreenDetailedIsInternal.value: A boolean value — true if the screen is internal, and false if it is external.

ScreenDetailedIsPrimary.summary:
NOTE Experimental The isPrimary read-only property of the
interface is a boolean indicating whether the screen is set as the operating system (OS) primary screen or not.

remarks.para: The OS hosting the browser will have one primary screen, and one or more secondary screens. The primary screen can usually be specified by the user via OS settings, and generally contains OS UI features such as the taskbar/icon dock. The primary screen may change for a number of reasons, such as a screen being unplugged.

ScreenDetailedIsPrimary.value: A boolean value — true if the screen is primary, and false if it is secondary.

ScreenDetailedLabel.summary:
NOTE Experimental The label read-only property of the
interface is a string providing a descriptive label for the screen, for example "Built-in Retina Display".

remarks.para: This is useful for constructing a list of options to display to the user if you want them to choose a screen to display content on.

ScreenDetailedLeft.summary:
NOTE Experimental The left read-only property of the
interface is a number representing the x-coordinate (left-hand edge) of the total screen area inside the OS virtual screen arrangement, relative to the multi-screen origin.

NOTE Experimental The top read-only property of the
